1343438500365012992.text: I look forward to working with the incoming Biden Administration to deliver continued federal relief so we can rise to the health and economic challenges this pandemic presents.

1343438499496783877.text: This legislation is an important step, but is far from our final one in the fight against COVID. We continue to feel the damage inflicted by this bruising pandemic, which will continue to require federal relief for our state and local governments.

1343438498594959361.text: Since May, my colleagues and I have worked to deliver additional relief for families and small businesses, which were blocked by partisan hurdles time and again.  Despite these challenges, my Problem Solvers Caucus colleagues and I continued to work with congressional leadership.

1343438497768726528.text:
Tonight the President signed our pandemic relief into law, ending his self-induced crisis.  Americans have waited far too long for continued relief, and this delay came at a cost.  
 https://t.co/Q8ipXw9ckh

1343326916779139072.text: We have passed a solid foundation to deliver aid that millions of Americans need NOW, including checks and UI. The president must sign this into law, and we will continue to do our jobs to help our country recover.

1343326915566952450.text: One more thing: because the relief bill and government funding bill were passed together, the government will shut down at midnight on Monday if the President does not sign the bill on his desk, which will further harm critical government services during this pandemic.

1343326914140917761.text: And yes, this will provide $600 checks, including for family members of immigrants who were unfairly left out of the last bill. While I support more, Republicans have blocked our immediate efforts to give Americans bigger direct payments.

1343326912932950016.text: For our farmworkers, who risk exposure to provide the food we eat, this bill provides $13 billion in agricultural assistance programs, including substantial funding to ensure farmworkers have the protective equipment they need to stay safe on the job.

1343326911771123712.text: For our students learning from home and impacted by the Digital Divide, this bill provides $7 billion in broadband funding, including over $3 billion for $50 monthly internet discounts.

1343326910483472395.text: Schools will struggle to reopen without funding for needed for safe learning environments. This relief bill would provide $82 billion for schools to helped them reopen safely.

1343326909258747906.text: State and local governments will lose access to CARES Act funds on January 1. This is funding to help communities, schools, renters, and small businesses respond to COVID-19 impacts. The relief bill will extend the funding availability for a year.

1343326907815911425.text: Small businesses who took PPP loans will face unexpected tax bills. This relief bill will prevent this unintended tax increase by allowing for deductions for standard expenses paid for with PPP funds.

1343326906553421829.text: Small businesses, many of which must close temporarily during this new surge of COVID cases, will continue to close permanently. The relief bill provides $284 billion for first and second PPP loans.

1343326905395793923.text: Food banks are overwhelmed and will be further stressed as workers lose UI benefits. This bill would provide $13 billion for nutrition benefits, boost SNAP, and provide $400 million in emergency funding for food banks.

1343326904191954944.text: The federal eviction moratorium ends on January 1st. Millions of people behind on their rent could be thrown onto the street during a pandemic. The relief bill would extend the eviction moratorium and provide $25 billion in rental assistance.

1343326902455562240.text: Federal emergency unemployment benefits affecting 14 million Americans expired today. The bill we sent to the President would extend these benefits, and provide $300 PER WEEK on top of underlying state benefits.

1343326901474091010.text: We are running out of time for the President to sign the COVID relief legislation. Here’s what’s at stake:

1236805622856921093.text: As we walk in their steps 55 years later, we recommit to continuing to fight for voting rights. We in the House proudly passed #HR4 the Voting Rights Advancement Act, to restore necessary voting protections and provide clear and consistent voting laws across the country.
